contentrichtext.text: {{BLP sources|date=August 2007}} {{Infobox congressman | name =Robert Underwood | image name = Underwood-GUal.jpg | birth_name = Robert Anacletus Underwood | birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1948|7|13|mf=y}} | birth_place= [[Tamuning, Guam]] | death_date = | death_place = | state = [[Guam]] | district = [[Guam's At-large congressional district|At-Large]] | term_start = January 3, 1993 | term_end = January 3, 2003 | preceded = [[Vicente T. Blaz|Ben Garrido Blaz]] | succeeded = [[Madeleine Bordallo]] | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] | order2 =10<sup>th</sup> President of the [[University of Guam]] | university =President of the [[University of Guam]] | term_start2 =May 21, 2008 | term_end2 = | preceded2 =[[Harold L. Allen]] | succeeded2 = | spouse = }} '''Robert Anacletus Underwood''' (born July 13, 1948) was a [[Delegate (United States Congress)|Delegate]] from [[Guam]] to the [[United States House of Representatives]]. ==Biography== [[Image:Wetlands-conservation-act.jpg|left|thumb|Underwood (far left) stands by President [[George W. Bush]] and other dignitaries for the signing of a bill.]] Underwood was born in [[Tamuning]], Guam, and attended [[California State University, Los Angeles]] and the [[University of Southern California]]. He became a high school teacher on the American mainland, and he then served as an instructor at the [[University of Guam]] from 1976 to 1983. Underwood was director of bilingual education assistance for [[Micronesia]] until 1988 and Academic Vice President of the University of Guam until 1992. Underwood was elected as a [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic]] Delegate to the [[United States House of Representatives]], serving from January 3, 1993 to January 3, 2003. He left the House in 2003 after an unsuccessful 2002 run for [[Governor of Guam]] against Republican [[Felix Perez Camacho]]. Underwood ran again as a Democrat for [[Governor of Guam]] in 2006, with running mate [[Frank Aguon]] for Lieutenant Governor. He defeated his main Democratic rival, former Guam governor [[Carl T.C. Gutierrez]], in the primary on September 3, 2006, [http://www.guampdn.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060903/NEWS01/60902001/1002] but again lost to incumbent Republican Governor [[Felix Perez Camacho]], 50%-48%. In 2008, Underwood was selected to begin a 5-year term as President of the [[University of Guam]]. ==External links== {{CongBio|U000014}} {{S-start}} {{S-par|us-hs}} {{USRSB|before=[[Vicente T. Blaz|Ben Garrido Blaz]]|type=Delegate |state=Guam|years=1993â€“2003|after=[[Madeleine Bordallo]]|}} {{s-aca}} {{succession box | before=[[Harold L. Allen]]| title=10<sup>th</sup> President of the [[University of Guam]]| years=May 21, 2008– Current | after= }} {{end box}} {{Guam Delegates}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Underwood, Robert A. | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Guam politiican | DATE OF BIRTH =July 13, 1948 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Tamuning, Guam]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Underwood, Robert A.}} [[Category:1948 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:California State University, Los Angeles alumni]] [[Category:Delegates to the United States House of Representatives from Guam]] [[Category:University of Southern California alumni]] [[Category:Guam Democrats]] [[Category:People from Tamuning, Guam]]
